<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="de">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>{{ title }}</title>
  <meta name="description" content="{{ description }}">
  {% if keywords %}<meta name="keywords" content="{{ keywords }}">{% endif %}
  <meta name="author" content="BOS-ARSA">
  <meta name="robots" content="index, follow">
  <link rel="canonical" href="{{ canonical }}">
  <!-- Open Graph -->
  <meta property="og:title" content="{{ title }}">
  <meta property="og:description" content="{{ ogDescription | default(description) }}">
  <meta property="og:type" content="website">
  <meta property="og:url" content="{{ canonical }}">
  <meta property="og:locale" content="de_AT">
  <meta property="og:site_name" content="BOS-ARSA">
  <meta property="og:image" content="{{ site.url }}/logo.webp?v=2">
  <meta property="og:image:width" content="800">
  <meta property="og:image:height" content="316">
  <meta property="og:image:alt" content="BOS-ARSA Logo">
  <!-- Twitter Card -->
  <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image">
  <meta name="twitter:title" content="{{ title }}">
  <meta name="twitter:description" content="{{ ogDescription | default(description) }}">
  <meta name="twitter:image" content="{{ site.url }}/logo.webp?v=2">
  {% if structuredData %}
  <!-- Structured Data -->
  <script type="application/ld+json">
  {{ structuredData | dump | safe }}
  </script>
  {% endif %}
  <link rel="icon" type="image/png" href="/favicon-96x96.png" sizes="96x96">
  <link rel="icon" type="image/svg+xml" href="/favicon.svg">
  <link rel="shortcut icon" href="/favicon.ico">
  <link rel="apple-touch-icon" sizes="180x180" href="/apple-touch-icon.png">
  <link rel="manifest" href="/site.webmanifest">
  <script src="https://unpkg.com/lucide@latest"></script>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="/css/base.css">
  {% if pageCSSFile %}<link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ pageCSSFile }}">{% endif %}
</head>
<body>

  {% include "nav.njk" %}

  {{ content | safe }}

  {% include "footer.njk" %}

  <script>
    lucide.createIcons();
    document.getElementById('year').textContent = new Date().getFullYear();

    // Nav scroll shadow
    const nav = document.getElementById('nav');
    window.addEventListener('scroll', () => {
      nav.classList.toggle('scrolled', window.scrollY > 20);
    }, { passive: true });

    // Mobile menu
    const navToggle = document.getElementById('navToggle');
    const navLinks = document.getElementById('navLinks');
    navToggle.addEventListener('click', () => {
      const isOpen = navLinks.classList.toggle('open');
      navToggle.classList.toggle('active');
      navToggle.setAttribute('aria-expanded', isOpen);
      navToggle.setAttribute('aria-label', isOpen ? 'Menü schließen' : 'Menü öffnen');
      document.body.style.overflow = isOpen ? 'hidden' : '';
    });
    navLinks.querySelectorAll('a').forEach(link => {
      link.addEventListener('click', () => {
        navLinks.classList.remove('open');
        navToggle.classList.remove('active');
        navToggle.setAttribute('aria-expanded', 'false');
        document.body.style.overflow = '';
      });
    });

    // Scroll reveal
    const observer = new IntersectionObserver((entries) => {
      entries.forEach(e => {
        if (e.isIntersecting) { e.target.classList.add('visible'); observer.unobserve(e.target); }
      });
    }, { threshold: 0.1, rootMargin: '0px 0px -30px 0px' });
    document.querySelectorAll('.reveal').forEach(el => observer.observe(el));

    // Stagger children
    document.querySelectorAll('.features, .board-grid').forEach(grid => {
      grid.querySelectorAll('.reveal').forEach((c, i) => { c.style.transitionDelay = `${i * .08}s`; });
    });
  </script>
</body>
</html>

Based on the search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA on the oevsv.at website:

BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) was founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

The goal of the organization is to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communications.

The organization is led by Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ) and currently holds its most important activity as a crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 7 PM on the 2m repeater of the LAWZ at 145.7625 MHz FM with an 88.5Hz subtone.

The organization is based in Klagenfurt, Austria, and can be reached at oe8gwq@oevsv.at or through their homepage at bos-arsa.at.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found:

Wolfgang Gabrutsch OE8GWQ reports about the BOS-ARSA project, an emergency radio project with connection to the radio services of emergency services organizations.

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks (BOS-ARSA) in 2019. Members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who have obtained an amateur radio license founded the association, with the goal of organizing interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of security organizations for crisis and disaster communication.

In this association, radio operators from emergency services organizations with amateur radio licenses can participate. The BOS-ARSA association currently has nearly 80 members.

For more information, you can visit www.bos-arsa.at or contact office@bos-arsa.at.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA Amateurfunk QSP ÖVSV:

## BOS-ARSA (BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria)

BOS-ARSA is the Austrian Amateur Radio Association for members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS), founded by those who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

**Purpose:** The association aims to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the dispatch centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

## QSP (Amateur Radio Journal)

QSP is the official amateur radio journal of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) that can be downloaded approximately 6 months after each publication date. Members receive the QSP publication approximately monthly.

## ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband)

The ÖVSV is a member of the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU) and is the umbrella organization of the Austrian amateur radio service. The ÖVSV aims to preserve and promote amateur radio in the broadest sense, including the establishment and operation of radio stations, research of propagation conditions, fostering contact and friendship between radio amateurs of all countries and territories, and assistance in disasters and emergencies.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA Amateurfunk QSP ÖVSV:

## BOS-ARSA (BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria)

BOS-ARSA is the Austrian Amateur Radio Association for members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS), founded by those who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

**Purpose:** The association aims to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the dispatch centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

## QSP (Amateur Radio Journal)

QSP is the official amateur radio journal of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) that can be downloaded approximately 6 months after each publication date. Members receive the QSP publication approximately monthly.

## ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband)

The ÖVSV is a member of the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU) and is the umbrella organization of the Austrian amateur radio service. The ÖVSV aims to preserve and promote amateur radio in the broadest sense, including the establishment and operation of radio stations, research of propagation conditions, fostering contact and friendship between radio amateurs of all countries and territories, and assistance in disasters and emergencies.

The goal of the association is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security responsibilities in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

## Organization and Membership

BOS-ARSA was founded in 2019 by Wolfgang Gabrutsch. The association currently has approximately 80 members.

## What is Amateurfunk?

An amateur radio operator is a person who engages in worldwide communication with like-minded individuals without pursuing commercial interests.

I found search results related to your query. Here's what I discovered:

## BOS-ARSA and Emergency Radio (Notfunk)

The BOS-ARSA initiatives involve setting up emergency radio stations that will be staffed by amateur radio operators in times of crisis and disaster, ensuring communication with emergency radio operators in the communities' light islands (Lichtinseln).

## QSP Magazine

QSP is an amateur radio journal from the Austrian Amateur Radio Association (ÖVSV), with published issues available for download from 2022, 2023, and 2024.

## ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association)

The ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband) is the interest representation for amateur radio operators in Austria. The core task of this independent and non-profit organization is the promotion of the internationally regulated amateur radio service and its members. Amateur radio operators operate worldwide experimental radio, including satellite, emergency and disaster radio.

## Emergency Radio (Notfunk) Overview

Emergency radio networks serve authorities and organizations (BOS) as well as the general public in case of telecommunications failure, with amateur radio operators providing one of the most important contributions in supporting authorities and relief organizations in emergency communications.

The search results show that BOS-ARSA is an important Austrian emergency communications initiative involving amateur radio operators, and QSP is the official magazine of the ÖVSV that covers these topics across 2022-2024.

content.content:
# BOS-ARSA Information Summary

**Organization Name & Purpose:**
"Österreichischen Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria" - an organization for licensed amateur radio operators from security and emergency services.

**Main Objective:**
The group aims to organize connections between ÖVSV's emergency communications system and command centers of security organizations for crisis and disaster communication.

**Leadership:**
Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ) serves as President and local section leader (ADL 820).

**Contact Information:**
- Email: oe8gwq@oevsv.at
- Address: Buchengasse 3, 9020 Klagenfurt am Wörthersee
- Homepage: http://www.bos-arsa.at/

**Activities:**
Weekly "Krisenkommunikationsübung" (crisis communication exercise) every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2m repeater 145.7625 MHz FM with 88.5 Hz subton.

**Links:**
- Main section page: http://oe8.oevsv.at/ortsstellen/adl820/
- BOS-ARSA website: http://www.bos-arsa.at/

**Associated Images:**
One photo from BOS-ARSA action event in Ferlach 2020 (credited to OE8DBK).

Based on the search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA and emergency radio exercises in the context of disaster protection:

BOS-ARSA (BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) was founded by members of authorities and organizations with security responsibilities (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses. The organization's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of security organizations as part of crisis and disaster communication.

Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of a blackout or other failure of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA has a permanent place in emergency services coordination. In emergency and disaster situations, amateur radio operators would operate radio stations in the crisis command centers to ensure communication with emergency radio operators in community "light islands" to provide support to the population in case conventional communication systems fail.

The search results reference various meetings and exercises related to BOS-ARSA and emergency radio, though they don't specifically detail "AOEC Katastrophenschutz" exercises by that exact name in the results retrieved. For more specific information about AOEC disaster protection exercises, you may want to search for additional sources or contact BOS-ARSA directly at office@bos-arsa.at.

Based on the search results, I found information about BOS-ARSA and ADL 820 related to emergency radio (Notfunk) activities in Carinthia (Kärnten), Austria:

## Overview

BOS-ARSA (Austrian Amateur Radio Society of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks) is a group that has established itself as its own local chapter ADL 820. The BOS-ARSA, also known as local chapter ADL 820, has dedicated itself to training and educating members of security authorities starting from Carinthia.

## Purpose and Activities

The association's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of ÖVSV and the control centers of security authorities within crisis and disaster communication. Members of rescue organizations, fire departments, lifeguards, and police are trained as radio amateurs and help in emergencies using amateur radio means.

## Regular Exercises

The most important activity is the crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 19:00 on the LAWZ 2m repeater on 145.7625 MHz FM with 88.5 Hz subaudible tone.

The search results did not contain specific information about exercises in 2022, 2023, or 2024. For more detailed information about exercises from those specific years, you may want to contact Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch OE8GWQ, who is listed as the president and contact person for ADL 820.

## What the Page Contains:

The webpage is a **static organizational website** for the Austrian Amateur Radio Association for Authorities and Security Organizations (BOS-ARSA). It features:

- **Organization Information**: Leadership structure including President Wolfgang Gabrutsch, General Secretary Erich Londer, and Treasurer René Camaur
- **Mission Statement**: "Preservation, promotion and dissemination of amateur radio within the scope of authorities and organizations with security tasks"
- **Recruitment Section**: Invitation for licensed amateur radio operators in BOS organizations to join
- **Contact Form**: A basic message submission form
- **Footer/Impressum**: Legal information with ZVR number 1783847541 and contact email office@bos-arsa.at

## No Dated Content Found:

The page contains no timestamped posts, articles, news items, or blog entries. It appears to be informational material about the organization rather than a content-driven blog or news publication.

## BOS-ARSA (Austrian Organization)

BOS-ARSA is the "Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria," an organization founded by members of Austrian authorities and security organizations (BOS) who have obtained amateur radio licenses.

## ADL 820

ADL 820 is a local section/club affiliated with BOS-ARSA, with President Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch based at the Regional Police Directorate of Carinthia in Klagenfurt. The organization's main activity is a crisis communication exercise held every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2m repeater at 145.7625 MHz FM with 88.5 Hz subtone.

## Key Distinction

It's important to note that BOS and amateur radio (AFu) are two completely different things – a BOS license is not sufficient for amateur radio operations; a separate amateur radio license is required. However, BOS-ARSA specifically bridges these worlds by bringing together individuals from security organizations who have obtained amateur radio licenses.

The search results show that BOS-ARSA and ADL 820 are Austrian-based organizations, not German ones, focusing on amateur radio operations for emergency and crisis communication.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA and the related topics:

## BOS-ARSA Overview

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the BOS-ARSA (Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks) in 2019. It is an emergency radio project with connections to the radio services of blue light organizations.

## Purpose and Crisis Communication

The organization's goal is to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication. Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of a blackout or other failure of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA has a fixed place at blue light meetings.

## Activities and Training

The most important activity is the crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 7 p.m., starting on the 2m repeater of LAWZ at 145.7625 MHz FM; 88.5 Hz subaudible tone.

## Membership

The BOS-ARSA association currently has approximately 80 members.

## Herbert Saurugg - Blackout and Crisis Preparedness Expert

Herbert Saurugg is an internationally recognized expert for blackout and crisis preparedness and president of the Society for Crisis Preparedness. He is the president of the Society for Crisis Preparedness (GfKV), an international blackout and crisis preparedness expert, keynote speaker, and idealist.

Herbert Saurugg has conducted numerous process consultations, workshops for preparation for a possible blackout, and trainings with blackout simulation for municipalities and crisis management teams called "Neustart".

## BOS Reference

In the context of Austrian emergency response, the communication network of the Austrian Ministry of the Interior (Digitalfunk-BOS Austria) works in a specially harmonized and standardized frequency band for crisis communication.

However, the search results don't contain specific details about "BOS-ARSA" as a formal cooperation or partnership. If you're looking for more specific information about a particular cooperation or initiative, you may want to contact Herbert Saurugg directly or visit the Society for Crisis Preparedness (GfKV) website.

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – Austrian Amateur Radio Society of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks) in 2019.

The association was founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who hold amateur radio licenses, with the goal of organizing and creating interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ) serves as the association's president. BOS-ARSA is an emergency radio project with connections to the radio services of the emergency services organizations (blue light organizations).

BOS-ARSA is an Austrian amateur radio association founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses. The association's goal is to organize interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

This session is being continued from a previous conversation that ran out of context. The summary below covers the earlier portion of the conversation. Analysis: Let me chronologically analyze the conversation: 1. **Initial Plan**: User provided a detailed plan to migrate BOS-ARSA website from static HTML to Eleventy (11ty) SSG. 2. **Reading existing files**: I read all existing HTML files (index.html, presse.html, impressum.html, datenschutz.html), SEO files (robots.txt, sitemap.xml, llms.txt), infrastructure files (nginx.conf, Dockerfile, docker-compose.yml, deploy-production.sh, .gitignore), and checked static assets. 3. **User interruption - technology choice**: User said "plan different technology", I asked what they wanted, they said "Astro", then immediately said "keep elementy... go on with your plan". 4. **npm init + Eleventy install**: Had to use `nix-shell -p nodejs_20` because NixOS doesn't have npm in PATH. 5. **Created directory structure and files**: .eleventy.js, src/_data/site.json, src/_data/presse.json, src/css/base.css, src/_includes/nav.njk, src/_includes/footer.njk, src/_includes/base.njk (using {% block %}), src/index.njk, src/presse.njk, src/impressum.njk, src/datenschutz.njk, src/robots.njk, src/sitemap.njk, src/llms.njk 6. **First build error - block inheritance**: The initial base.njk used `{% block content %}{% endblock %}` but Eleventy's layout system uses `{{ content | safe }}`, NOT Nunjucks block inheritance. The presse page rendered empty. Fixed by: - Changing base.njk to use `{{ content | safe }}` - Adding `pageCSSFile` front matter variable for page-specific CSS - Using `structuredData` front matter (YAML object rendered with `dump | safe`) - Creating separate src/css/index.css for homepage styles - Removing all `{% block %}` tags from child templates 7. **Nav prefix bug**: Homepage nav links were `/ueber-uns` instead of `#ueber-uns`. Fixed by changing the Nunjucks variable from `"/"` to `"#"` for home pages. 8. **Deleted old files**: Removed index.html, presse.html, impressum.html, datenschutz.html, robots.txt, sitemap.xml, llms.txt from root. 9. **Updated package.json**: Added build and dev scripts. 10. **User said "deploy"**: Ran deploy-production.sh successfully. 11. **User said site wasn't deployed properly, presse.html still exists**: User requested clean URLs (`/presse` instead of `/presse.html`). 12. **Clean URLs implementation**: - Changed permalinks to `/presse/`, `/impressum/`, `/datenschutz/` (outputs directory/index.html) - Updated all internal links in nav.njk, footer.njk, sitemap.njk - Updated canonical URLs in front matter - Updated nginx.conf with `try_files $uri $uri/ $uri/index.html =404` and 301 redirects for old .html URLs 13. **Committed and deployed**: "Auf Eleventy (11ty) migrieren mit Clean URLs" 14. **User: "fix also link zur wasserettung = owr.at"**: Changed the Wasserrettung link from `https://www.oesterreichische-wasserrettung.at` to `https://owr.at` in src/index.njk. 15. **Deployed the fix**. 16. **User: "add og information to have preview in social media"**: Checked - OG tags were already present on all pages from base.njk. Informed user. 17. **User: "create a dedicated og image 1200x630"**: Used ImageMagick via nix-shell to create og-image.png (1200x630) with dark navy background, centered logo, and tagline. - First attempt with `convert` failed (deprecated in IMv7, font not found) - Used `magick` command with local woff2 font file - Updated base.njk to reference og-image.png instead of logo.webp - Initially added redundant passthrough copy for og-image.png which caused build error (conflicted with existing `*.png` passthrough) - removed it - Deployed successfully 18. **User: "commit this"**: Committed both the OG image and Wasserrettung link fix together, pushed. 19. **User: "ergänze noch presse & medien"**: Search for new press articles about BOS-ARSA, OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ, including QSP archive. 20. **Current search work**: Multiple web searches and fetches performed. Found: - The ADL 820 page on oe8.oevsv.at - BOS-ARSA WordPress site (static, no blog posts) - Spotify/Apple Podcasts episodes (already in presse.json) - Saurugg.net reference but no BOS-ARSA mention - Notfunk Deutschland has no BOS-ARSA mention - QSP PDFs couldn't be text-searched via WebFetch - A background agent (aba31b9) was launched and is still running - No significant NEW articles found yet beyond what's already on the press page - The Spotify page mentioned an "EMCOM" episode (Jan 18, 2026) which might be related but needs verification The search is still ongoing - I was about to check more sources when the summary was requested. Summary: 1. Primary Request and Intent: The user requested a full migration of the BOS-ARSA website (Austrian amateur radio association for public safety organizations) from static HTML files to Eleventy (11ty) static site generator. The migration includes: shared layouts/partials (nav, footer, base), data-driven press page from JSON, generated SEO files, clean URLs without .html extensions, a multi-stage Docker build, and a dedicated OG image for social media previews. The most recent request is to find and add new press/media articles about BOS-ARSA by searching the web for mentions of BOS-ARSA, OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ, and the ÖVSV QSP archive. 2. Key Technical Concepts: - Eleventy (11ty) v3.1.2 with Nunjucks templating - Eleventy layout system uses `{{ content | safe }}`, NOT Nunjucks `{% block %}` inheritance - Page-specific CSS via `pageCSSFile` front matter variable - Structured data via `structuredData` front matter (YAML object, rendered with `dump | safe`) - Nav prefix logic: `activeNav: "home"` → `#` anchors, other pages → `/#` anchors - Clean URLs: permalink `/presse/` outputs `presse/index.html`, served by nginx - SEO files generated from templates with `eleventyExcludeFromCollections: true` - Docker multi-stage build: node:20-alpine builds site, nginx:alpine serves _site/ - NixOS: Node.js accessed via `nix-shell -p nodejs_20` - ImageMagick (`magick` command, not deprecated `convert`) for OG image generation - Passthrough copy conflicts: `*.png` glob already covers `og-image.png` 3. Files and Code Sections: - **`.eleventy.js`** — Eleventy config, input: src/, output: _site/, passthrough copy for fonts, favicon, mp4, png, webp, CSS ```javascript module.exports = function(eleventyConfig) { eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({ "fonts": "fonts" }); eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({ "favicon": "/" }); eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({ "*.mp4": "/" }); eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({ "*.png": "/" }); eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy({ "*.webp": "/" }); eleventyConfig.addPassthroughCopy("src/css"); return { dir: { input: "src", output: "_site", includes: "_includes", data: "_data" }, templateFormats: ["njk", "md"], htmlTemplateEngine: "njk", markdownTemplateEngine: "njk" }; }; ``` - **`src/_includes/base.njk`** — Main layout with head, nav include, `{{ content | safe }}`, footer include, shared JS. Uses conditional `pageCSSFile` and `structuredData` front matter. OG image references `/og-image.png` (1200x630). - **`src/_includes/nav.njk`** — Navigation partial with smart prefix logic (`#` for home, `/#` for subpages), active state for presse link, clean URL `/presse/` ```nunjucks {% set prefix = "#" if activeNav == "home" else "/#" %}
  • Über uns
    • ...
  • Presse
    • ``` - **`src/_includes/footer.njk`** — Footer with data from site.json, clean URL links (`/impressum/`, `/datenschutz/`, `/presse/`) - **`src/_data/site.json`** — Global site data (name, fullName, legalName, url, email, address, zvr, vereinsbehoerde, websiteBetreiber) - **`src/_data/presse.json`** — 6 press articles with date, tag, tagLabel, title, url, source, desc fields - **`src/css/base.css`** — All shared styles: fonts, CSS variables, reset, nav, footer, buttons, sections, page-content, article cards, responsive breakpoints - **`src/css/index.css`** — Homepage-specific styles: hero, video, features, board grid, goals, join section, partners, responsive - **`src/index.njk`** — Homepage with structuredData in YAML front matter, pageCSSFile: "/css/index.css", activeNav: home, Wasserrettung link updated to `https://owr.at` - **`src/presse.njk`** — Data-driven press page looping over `presse` data, permalink: `/presse/` - **`src/impressum.njk`** — Impressum with data from site.json, permalink: `/impressum/` - **`src/datenschutz.njk`** — Datenschutz with data from site.json, permalink: `/datenschutz/` - **`src/robots.njk`**, **`src/sitemap.njk`**, **`src/llms.njk`** — Generated SEO files using site.url - **`Dockerfile`** — Multi-stage: node:20-alpine builds, nginx:alpine serves ```dockerfile FROM node:20-alpine AS build WORKDIR /app COPY package*.json ./ RUN npm ci --production COPY . . RUN npx @11ty/eleventy FROM nginx:alpine RUN rm /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/bosarsa.conf COPY --from=build /app/_site/ /usr/share/nginx/html/ EXPOSE 80 ``` - **`nginx.conf`** — Updated with clean URL support, 301 redirects for old .html URLs, CSS caching - **`og-image.png`** — 1200x630 OG image with dark navy background (#0F1A2E), centered logo, tagline - **`package.json`** — devDependencies: @11ty/eleventy ^3.1.2, scripts: build, dev - **`.gitignore`** — *.mp4, _site/, node_modules/ 4. Errors and fixes: - **Nunjucks block inheritance doesn't work with Eleventy layouts**: base.njk used `{% block content %}{% endblock %}` but Eleventy's layout system uses `{{ content | safe }}`. Presse page rendered empty. Fixed by switching to `{{ content | safe }}` and removing all block tags, using front matter variables for page-specific CSS and structured data. - **Nav prefix wrong on homepage**: `navPrefix = "/"` produced `/ueber-uns` instead of `#ueber-uns`. Fixed by changing to `prefix = "#"` for home. - **ImageMagick `convert` deprecated**: Used `magick` instead. Font `Inter` not found system-wide, used local woff2 path. - **Passthrough copy conflict**: Adding explicit `og-image.png` passthrough conflicted with existing `*.png` glob, causing ENOTEMPTY error. Fixed by removing the redundant entry since `*.png` already covers it. - **npm not found**: NixOS doesn't have npm in PATH. Fixed by using `nix-shell -p nodejs_20 --run "..."`. - **User feedback - presse.html still on prod**: User noted old .html files still existed. Led to clean URLs implementation. - **User feedback - Wasserrettung link**: User specified correct URL should be owr.at, not oesterreichische-wasserrettung.at. 5. Problem Solving: - Successfully migrated 4 HTML pages to Eleventy templates with shared layout - Eliminated ~150+ lines of duplicated boilerplate per page - Made press articles data-driven (add JSON entry = add article) - Implemented clean URLs with nginx support and 301 redirects - Created OG image for social media previews - Multiple successful deployments via deploy-production.sh 6. All user messages: - "Implement the following plan: [detailed Eleventy migration plan]" - "[Request interrupted by user]plan different technology" - "Astro" (answer to technology question) - "[Request interrupted by user]keep elementy... go on with your plan" - "deploy" - "not deployed, as presse.html still exists on prod[Request interrupted by user]do not want to have html files ... like presse.html... can we /presse instead" - "deploy" - "fix also link zur wasserettung = owr.at" - "deploy" - "add og information to have preview in social media" - "create a dedicated og image 1200x630" - "commit this" - "commit this and deploy" - "es elemetnly now live" - "ergänze noch presse & medien. suche ob du irgendwas zu BOS ARSA, OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ etc. findest. du kannst auch das qsp archiv des övsv durchsuchen" 7. Pending Tasks: - Complete the search for new press/media articles about BOS-ARSA - Add any found articles to `src/_data/presse.json` - Deploy the updated press page - A background search agent (aba31b9) is still running 8. Current Work: Searching the web for new press articles about BOS-ARSA to add to the press page. The user said: "ergänze noch presse & medien. suche ob du irgendwas zu BOS ARSA, OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ etc. findest. du kannst auch das qsp archiv des övsv durchsuchen" Multiple web searches have been performed for BOS-ARSA, OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ, QSP archive, and related terms. So far, no significant NEW articles have been found beyond the 6 already in presse.json. Sources checked: - oevsv.at (found ADL 820 page, existing Fachgespräch article) - bosarsa.wordpress.com (static page, no articles) - Spotify/Apple Podcasts (existing episodes already listed) - saurugg.net (no BOS-ARSA mention) - notfunk-deutschland.de (no BOS-ARSA mention) - QSP PDFs (couldn't extract text via WebFetch) - Various web searches for callsigns A background agent (aba31b9) was launched to do parallel searching and is still running. The Spotify page mentioned an "EMCOM" episode (Jan 18, 2026) that might be related but needs verification. I was about to do more searches when the summary was requested. 9. Based on the search results, here's information about BOS-ARSA Amateurfunk Österreich:

## Overview

BOS-ARSA is an Austrian amateur radio association founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses. The full name is "Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben (BOS) - Amateur Radio Society Austria (BOS-ARSA)" and the organization is based in Klagenfurt.

## Purpose and Goals

The association's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communications.

## Founding

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the association in 2019. Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch, BA MBA MBA (call sign OE8GWQ), serves as president.

## Activities

The organization's main activity is crisis communication exercises held every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2-meter repeater of LAWZ on 145.7625 MHz FM with an 88.5Hz subtone. BOS-ARSA also organizes amateur radio training courses to prepare participants for licensing exams.

For more information, you can visit their website at www.bos-arsa.at or contact office@bos-arsa.at.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about Gabrutsch and Amateurfunk:

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks (BOS-ARSA) in 2019. Gabrutsch is a police officer who is relatively new to amateur radio and, unlike most radio amateurs, does not come from a technical background.

BOS-ARSA was founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks who have obtained amateur radio licenses. The goal of the association is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

In 2019, Gabrutsch completed his training and exam and has held his radio license since that time, which allows him to work with 100-watt devices and build them himself.

Here are the search results for "BOS Amateur Radio Society Austria":

The BOS-ARSA (BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) was founded by members of the Austrian authorities and organizations with security tasks who have obtained amateur radio licenses. The organization's full name in German is "Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria (BOS-ARSA)".

The organization has an online presence with a WordPress website at bosarsa.wordpress.com and appears to be affiliated with the broader Austrian amateur radio community organized under the ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband).

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about BOS-ARSA on Spotify:

BOS-ARSA is the "Österreichischen Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben" (Austrian Amateur Radio Society for Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks), founded by members of authorities and security organizations who have obtained amateur radio licenses.

The project focuses on emergency radio communications with connections to the radio services of emergency response organizations, within the framework of crisis and disaster communication.

The podcast "ON AIR - Amateurfunk D-A-CH" features episodes about BOS-ARSA on Spotify, including discussions about training and education within the organization. More information is available at www.bos-arsa.at

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the QSP magazine archive from oevsv.at:

## QSP Magazine Archive Access

QSP magazine exemplars from the Austrian Amateur Radio Association (ÖVSV) can be downloaded approximately 6 months after their respective publication date. 

The search results show several access points:

1. **Main Download Page**: The ÖVSV downloads page features current and recent issues from different years (2025, 2024, etc.)

2. **Archive URLs**: There are dedicated archive sections:
   - http://archiv.oevsv.at/oevsv/qsp (main QSP archive)
   - http://archiv.oe1.oevsv.at/termine/qsp.html (Vienna regional archive)

3. **Magazine Details**: QSP is the club magazine that appears monthly in the first days of each month and is created by a volunteer editorial team, containing current information about amateur radio services from national and international areas, internal association information and reports.

The archives contain issues from multiple years (2019-2025 visible in the search results), allowing you to access historical editions of the magazine.

Based on the search results for "oevsv.at BOS-ARSA," here's what I found:

BOS-ARSA is an Austrian Amateur Radio Association founded by members of authorities and organizations with security responsibilities (BOS - Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben) who have acquired amateur radio licenses. The full name is "Österreichischen Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria."

The organization's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security responsibilities in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of blackouts or other failures of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA has secured a permanent place at the "Blaulicht-Stammtisch" (blue light gathering). In the emergency operations room, they have planned to establish a club radio station that will be staffed by BOS amateur radio operators in crisis and disaster cases, and will also ensure communication to emergency radio operators in light islands of communities for providing support to the population in case of failure of conventional communication means.

More information can be found at www.bos-arsa.at, and you can contact them at office@bos-arsa.at.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

# Article Summary

**Title:** Kurzwelle & Co: Die Welt der Funkamateure

**Publication Date:** April 28, 2021

**Author:** Bernhard Knaus

---

## Key Content

The article explores amateur radio as a hobby, featuring Oberst Wolfgang Gabrutsch from Feistritz im Rosental as the primary subject.

**BOS-ARSA Organization:**
Gabrutsch founded "BOS-ARSA" in 2019, described as the "Austrian amateur radio association of authorities and organizations with safety tasks." The organization currently has approximately 80 members and recently joined the ÖVSV umbrella organization.

**Call Sign:**
Gabrutsch's amateur radio call sign is "OE8GWQ," where "OE" represents Austria and "8" denotes Carinthia.

**Key Statistics:**
- 6,760 licensed amateur radio operators nationwide in Austria
- 572 in Carinthia
- 89 in Klagenfurt City
- 26 in Klagenfurt Land

**Emergency Preparedness:**
The article emphasizes amateur radio operators' legal obligation to support authorities during crises. It discusses blackout scenarios and notes that amateur relay stations are being equipped with independent power supplies to maintain communication when conventional systems fail.

# Podcast Episode Details

**Title:** "BOS-ARSA, Ausbildung"

**Date:** December 10, 2021

**Description:** This episode features Lukas Spitzer (OE8LSR) discussing training and education within the BOS-ARSA organization.

## About BOS-ARSA

BOS-ARSA is the "Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks." The episode explains that members are "public safety personnel who obtained amateur radio licenses" and formed this group to serve emergency communications.

The organization's primary objective involves "creating interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and emergency dispatch centers" during crises and disasters.

## Episode Content

The roughly 21-minute segment focuses on how BOS-ARSA prepares its members through specialized training programs, bridging amateur radio capabilities with official emergency response infrastructure in Austria, Germany, and Switzerland.

I found search results for "site:oevsv.at BOS-ARSA". Here are the key findings:

BOS-ARSA (BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) is an organization founded by members of security and emergency organizations (BOS) who have obtained amateur radio licenses.

The organization's goal is to organize interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) and the dispatch centers of security and emergency organizations for crisis and disaster communication.

Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ) is the president, based at the State Police Directorate Carinthia in Klagenfurt. The main activity is a crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2m repeater.

Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of blackouts or infrastructure failures, BOS-ARSA has a regular presence in emergency service meetings, and a radio station is planned at the district office in Völkermarkt to be staffed by BOS amateur radio operators in crisis situations to maintain communication with emergency radio operators in local communities.

I've completed a web search for your query about "Notfunk Österreich BOS Amateurfunk Katastrophenfunk" (Emergency Radio Austria - Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks - Amateur Radio - Disaster Radio). Here are the key results:

## What is Notfunk (Emergency Radio)?

Notfunk (or Katastrophenfunk/Disaster Radio) refers to radio operation where amateur radio operators provide assistance within their communication capabilities during emergency and disaster situations.

## Role in Austria

Amateur radio operators support aid organizations and other authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS), or relay received emergency calls to these organizations. In Austria, this work is coordinated by the ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband - Austrian Amateur Radio Association).

## Key Activities

Every May 1st, the AOEE (All_OE_Exercise) emergency and disaster radio exercise takes place, where amateur radio operators from throughout Austria attempt to establish connections with all political districts on the 80m and 40m bands at different times of day.

## Infrastructure and Equipment

With a globally established network of relay stations and network-independent amateur radio stations, data and message exchange via radio is ensured at all times. The Austrian Red Cross has integrated licensed amateur radio operators as voluntary workers in telecom units in all federal states, who can operate the amateur radio service during disasters.

The search results provide extensive information about Austria's emergency radio service and its integration with official emergency response organizations.

content.content:
# ADL 820 - BOS-ARSA Information Extract

## Organization Overview
ADL 820 represents "Österreichischen Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-ARSA" (Austrian Amateur Radio Association for Security Organizations). The group aims to "create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of ÖVSV and dispatch centers of security authorities in crisis and disaster communication."

## Leadership
**Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ)** serves as both organization president and ADL 820 group leader. He holds the title of deputy emergency radio department head and has been licensed since 2019.

**Contact:** oe8gwq@oevsv.at

## Activities
The primary recurring activity is a crisis communication exercise held "every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2m repeater at 145.7625 MHz FM with 88.5 Hz subton." Regular club meetings are currently not scheduled.

## Online Resources
- Homepage: http://www.bos-arsa.at/
- Regional page: http://oe8.oevsv.at/ortsstellen/adl820/

content.content:
# BOS-ARSA and NOTFUNK Article Summary

**Date:** July 13, 2021

**Main Event:** A specialist discussion on emergency radio operations and BOS-ARSA-ADL820 took place on July 10 at Pressegger See in Carinthia.

**Callsigns Mentioned:**
- OE3KYS, OE8IMK, OE8SCQ, OE8OWK, OE8FCK, OE8GWQ, PE1AVP
- (Note: OE8OPT and OE8AWZ are not mentioned in this article)

**Key Content:**
The gathering featured professionals exchanging experiences and developing future plans. OE8SCQ presented infrastructure for QSO communications via QO100 satellite.

**Additional Activities:**
BOS-ARSA representatives welcomed DX-Camp participants in Döbriach on July 10. On July 12, the organization participated in a "Blaulicht-Stammtisch" (emergency services meeting) in Völkermarkt, where plans were announced for establishing an amateur radio station in the district administrator's crisis center.

**QSP Magazine:** No references to QSP magazine appear in this article.

**Author:** Kevin Mekul (OE8KKM)

content.content:
# BOS-ARSA Website Content Analysis

## Organization Overview
BOS-ARSA is an Austrian amateur radio association for authorities and organizations with security tasks ("Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben").

## Key Information Provided

**Leadership Structure:**
- President: Wolfgang Gabrutsch, BA MBA MBA DBA
- General Secretary: Erich Londer, BA
- Treasurer: René Camaur (Ing.)
- Secretary: Jürgen Kugi

**Stated Purpose:**
The organization aims to maintain, promote, and distribute amateur radio activities within "Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben (BOS)" scope.

**Contact & Legal Details:**
- Email: office@bos-arsa.at
- Address: 9020 Klagenfurt am Wörthersee, Buchengasse 3
- ZVR number: 1783847541
- Supervisory authority: Landespolizeidirektion Kärnten

**Recruitment:**
The site invites individuals with amateur radio licenses working in BOS organizations to join via a contact form.

## Metadata Limitations
The page contains no visible publication or update dates. The copyright statement reads "2020" but no creation or modification timestamps are displayed. No press mentions or external media links are included in the visible content.

content.content:
# Amateur Radio Training Course Article Summary

**Date:** October 5-7, 2021

**Article Topic:** This article covers an amateur radio certification course completed by water rescue personnel in Austria.

**Key Details:**

Eight rescue workers from Austrian Water Rescue Carinthia completed an amateur radio course and examination in September 2021. The five-day training program was organized by "BOS-ARSA (Austrian Amateur Radio Association for Authorities and Organizations with Safety Tasks)" and held at the Red Cross rescue station in Ferlach.

The curriculum included: "technical fundamentals, radio and operating procedures and legal requirements."

On September 30, participants passed their final examination administered by Austria's telecommunications authority in Klagenfurt, earning a "CEPT-License" (Category 1 amateur radio certification) that qualifies them to operate in all authorized amateur frequency bands.

The organization estimates approximately 50 volunteer hours were invested in training and examination. These newly certified operators will primarily support disaster response efforts and regional/national water rescue deployments going forward.

**Source Referenced:** The article directs readers to the Austrian Republic's telecommunications authority homepage for additional amateur radio service information.

# Article Analysis

## Title
"TETRA Funk zivil und bei BOS" (TETRA Radio in Civil and Emergency Services)

## Date
Published April 19, 2022

## Author
mhaiderer

## Summary
This article explains TETRA (Terrestrial Trunked Radio), a digital communications system used by both amateur radio operators and BOS (Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben—authorities and organizations with security responsibilities). The piece describes how BOS operates encrypted radio networks on 390-395 MHz frequencies across Austria with extensive base station coverage. Amateur radio operators can access unencrypted TETRA repeaters on the 70cm band at locations like Exelberg and Donauturm. The article notes that both systems use unique identification methods—DMR-IDs for amateur radio and SIM cards for BOS—enabling global communication across various talk groups. It raises questions about communication continuity during power outages or blackouts, promising future discussion of these emergency scenarios.

## BOS-ARSA Mentions
There are **no mentions of "BOS-ARSA"** in the provided content.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about these terms:

**BOS-ARSA:** BOS-ARSA is the Austrian Amateur Radio Society of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks (Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben - Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria), founded by members of these authorities and organizations who have obtained amateur radio licenses.

**QSP:** QSP is a monthly Austrian magazine for amateur radio published by the Austrian Amateur Radio Association (ÖVSV), serving as its official and nonpartisan organ. The magazine's name refers to the Q-code, where QSP stands for the free relaying of a message.

**ÖVSV:** This is the Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband (Austrian Amateur Radio Association), which is the parent organization that publishes QSP.

These terms are all connected within the Austrian amateur radio community, with BOS-ARSA being a specialized amateur radio society, and QSP being the official magazine of the umbrella ÖVSV organization.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA in connection with water rescue and amateur radio in Carinthia:

## BOS-ARSA Overview

BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben) was founded by members of security organizations (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

The organization's goal is to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of security organizations within crisis and disaster communication.

## Connection to Water Rescue (Wasserrettung)

BOS-ARSA organizes training courses for Austrian Water Rescue (ÖWR) personnel, and the trained "radio operators" are subsequently used primarily in disaster protection operations and in emergency water rescue operations.

## Activities in Carinthia (Kärnten)

Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of blackouts or other critical infrastructure failures, BOS-ARSA has secured a permanent place at the "Blaulicht-Stammtisch" (emergency services meeting). A radio station is planned in the emergency operations center of the Völkermarkt District, which will be staffed by BOS amateur radio operators in crisis and disaster cases and operated in the context of the message collection point to ensure communication with emergency radio operators in light islands throughout communities.

Based on the search results, "OE8OPT" appears to be an Austrian amateur radio callsign. Amateur radio callsigns are designations for radio stations in the amateur radio service and typically consist of three parts: a prefix, a digit (numeral), and a suffix.

In this case:
- **OE** is the prefix indicating Austria (OE is the country code for Austrian amateur radio callsigns)
- **8** is the numeral/digit representing the region (Region 8 is typically associated with the Carinthia/Vorarlberg area in Austria)
- **OPT** is the suffix (letters assigned to the individual operator)

The search results show that Austria manages its amateur radio service through the ÖVSV (Österreichischer Versuchssenderverband - Austrian Amateur Radio Association), and OE callsigns are issued according to specific regulations by the Austrian telecommunications authority.

# QSP Magazine Downloads (2020-2025)

The ÖVSV website provides QSP journal issues organized by year. Here are the available download ranges:

**2025**: Issues 01-07/08 available
**2024**: Complete year (12 issues) available
**2023**: Complete year (12 issues) available
**2022**: Complete year (12 issues) available
**2021**: Complete year (12 issues) available
**2020**: Complete year (12 issues) available

## Access Note

According to the page: "Hier können die Exemplare des ÖVSV Amateurfunkjournals QSP **ungefähr** **6 Monate nach dem jeweiligen Erscheinungsdatum** heruntergeladen werden"

This indicates publications become available approximately 6 months after their release date.

All issues are available as PDF files through direct download links organized in the QSP Download section of the ÖVSV website. Each issue links to its respective PDF hosted on the ÖVSV servers.

content.content:
# Article Summary: "Funken im Katastrophenfall"

**Title:** Funken im Katastrophenfall (Radio in Case of Disaster)

**Date:** October 5-6, 2021

**Main Topic:**
This article describes how eight water rescue personnel from Austrian Water Rescue Carinthia completed an amateur radio course and certification exam in September 2021 to ensure emergency communication capabilities when conventional systems fail.

**Key Details:**

The training was organized by **BOS-ARSA** (Austrian Amateur Radio Association for Public Safety Organizations), held at the Red Cross rescue station in Ferlach. As stated in the article: "Bei einem 5-tägigem Kurs...konnten sich die Teilnehmer bestens auf die Abschluss" (During a 5-day course, participants prepared thoroughly for the final exam).

Participants studied technical fundamentals, radio operations, and legal regulations, investing approximately 50 volunteer hours total. One rescue worker mentioned by name is Christoph Sterbenz.

**Purpose:**
The newly certified "radio operators" will primarily serve during disaster response operations and for state/federal water rescue missions when standard communication infrastructure is unavailable.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about BOS-ARSA. Here's what the search revealed:

BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben) was founded in 2019 by Wolfgang Gabrutsch.

The organization allows radio amateurs who work for emergency services organizations ("Blaulicht-Organisationen") with amateur radio licenses to participate. 

The organization aims to support authorities and organizations with security tasks in the event of a disaster, with specific preparation for blackout scenarios by establishing communication stations in each emergency service organization that would be operated by their members.

The organization was recently incorporated into the ÖVSV (the umbrella organization of radio amateurs) with representation and voting rights.

In essence, BOS-ARSA is an Austrian amateur radio association specifically designed to connect amateur radio operators (Amateurfunk) with emergency services (Feuerwehr/Fire Department, Polizei/Police, Rettung/Rescue services) for disaster communication and emergency support purposes.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about BOS-ARSA and Katastrophenschutz (disaster management):

## BOS-ARSA Overview

BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) is an organization founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

## Purpose and Goals

The association's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the emergency centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communications.

## Blackout Relevance

Due to the need for alternative communication options in the event of a blackout or other failure of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA has taken on a fixed place in disaster response planning. In the event of a crisis or disaster, BOS amateur radio operators are deployed in emergency operations centers where they maintain communications with emergency radio operators in the light islands (areas with backup power) of municipalities to ensure that appropriate support reaches the population in case of failure of conventional communication means.

The organization plays an important role in Austria's disaster management infrastructure, particularly in ensuring that authorities can communicate when normal communication systems fail during widespread power outages.

Links: [{"title":"BOS-ARSA und NOTFUNK – Fachgespräch in Kärnten","url":"https://www.oevsv.REDACTED"},{"title":"ADL 820 - BOS-ARSA","url":"https://oe8.oevsv.at/ortsstellen/adl820/"},{"title":"Bezirksstelle Völkermarkt - Dienststellenkontakt - WKO","url":"https://www.wko.at/department/55"},{"title":"Geänderte Öffnungszeiten in der Bezirksstelle Völkermarkt | Arbeiterkammer Kärnten","url":"https://kaernten.arbeiterkammer.at/ueberuns/kontakt/beratungszentren/Geaenderte-Oeffnungszeiten-in-der-Bezirksstelle-Voelkerma.html"},{"title":"BOS-Funk – Wikipedia","url":"https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/BOS-Funk"},{"title":"Liste der BOS-Leitstellen – Wikipedia","url":"https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_der_BOS-Leitstellen"},{"title":"BOS Digitale Funk Masten","url":"https://www.funkfrequenzen01.de/bos_digi001.htm"},{"title":"BOS Austria Digitalfunk","url":"https://www.bergrettung-stmk.at/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Organisations%C3%BCbergreifende-FSO-BOS-Steiermark-V-02_2020.pdf"},{"title":"BOS - FMS - Kennungen - Deutschland","url":"http://www.funkfrequenzen01.de/bos011.htm"},{"title":"Allgemeine Verwaltungsvorschrift zur Nutzung und den Betrieb allgemeiner sowie spezialisierter Funkanwendungen der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben (Funkrichtlinie Funkanwendungen BOS)","url":"https://www.verwaltungsvorschriften-im-internet.de/bsvwvbund_08072024_B5.htm"}]

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about BOS-ARSA and Völkermarkt:

BOS-ARSA (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) is an association founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

The association's goal is to organize and create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

Regarding the Völkermarkt connection: In the emergency operations center of the District Authority (BH) Völkermarkt, a club radio station is planned that will be staffed by BOS amateur radio operators in crisis and disaster situations and will be operated in the area of the message collection point.

The organization is led by Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch (OE8GWQ) and the most important activity is a crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 7 p.m., starting on the 2m repeater of the LAWZ on 145.7625 MHz FM with an 88.5 Hz subtone.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about this query:

BOS-ARSA is the "Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks" (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben), which is for members of emergency and security organizations who hold amateur radio licenses.

The organization's goal is to organize interfaces between the existing emergency radio system and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks for crisis and disaster communication.

Regarding "OE8OPT" - this follows the Austrian amateur radio callsign structure. Amateur radio callsigns consist of three parts: prefix, numeral, and suffix. In this case, "OE8" is the prefix (indicating Austria), and "OPT" is the suffix.

While the search results show information about BOS-ARSA and indicate that suffixes beginning with X are club callsigns for amateur radio associations, the specific callsign "OE8OPT" and its exact association with BOS-ARSA as a club callsign (Klubrufzeichen) is not explicitly detailed in these results. You may find more specific information about this particular callsign on the official BOS-ARSA website (bos-arsa.at) or through the Austrian amateur radio regulatory authority.

Based on the search results, I found information related to your query about "bos-arsa.at Presse Medien Berichte" (Press Media Reports):

The search results show that BOS-ARSA (an Austrian emergency services amateur radio organization) conducts various activities and expert discussions, including a technical discussion on emergency communications at Pressegger See.

BOS-ARSA has been involved in presenting their goals to authorities and organizations with security tasks, including the fire department, Austrian Armed Forces, and other emergency services.

The organization plays a role in emergency communications infrastructure, with plans for establishing radio stations in crisis and disaster situations to maintain communication with emergency responders and the population.

I've completed the web search for "Kleine Zeitung" Funkamateure BOS Kärnten 2024 2025. Here are the results:

The search returned several relevant results about amateur radio (Funkamateure), BOS (emergency services communications), and Carinthia (Kärnten):

1. **Kleine Zeitung article mention**: A reference to an article in the Kleine Zeitung titled "Wie ein alter Funkdienst die Grundlage für moderne Technologien bildete" (How an old radio service formed the basis for modern technologies) from November 10, 2024.

2. **BOS-ARSA in Carinthia**: The Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Public Safety Organizations (BOS-ARSA) was founded in 2019 by Wolfgang Gabrutsch. Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch serves as President of ADL 820 (BOS-ARSA), and their main activity is a crisis communication exercise held every Sunday at 19:00 on the 2m repeater.

3. **Digitalfunk expansion**: The Digitalfunk BOS Austria is planned to be expanded to provide full coverage in Carinthia.

4. **Amateur radio licensing**: In Carinthia, there are 572 licensed amateur radio operators (Funkamateure).

The results show active coverage of amateur radio activities and emergency communications infrastructure in Carinthia in local news sources like Kleine Zeitung.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about "Citizen Science" in relation to BOS-ARSA and Amateurfunk Österreich:

A presentation by Mike Zwingl (OE3MZC) from the 25th Radio Exhibition in Laa an der Thaya provided an overview of how Citizen Science contributes to advancing research progress and disaster protection.

Regarding BOS-ARSA itself, it is an association founded by members of emergency and security organizations (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses, with the goal of organizing interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of emergency and security organizations in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

The connection appears to be that citizen science initiatives within the amateur radio community contribute to both research advancement and emergency response capabilities, with BOS-ARSA serving as a specialized organization for emergency and security personnel involved in amateur radio.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the connections between Institute Citizen Science, Amateur Radio (Amateurfunk), and BOS (Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben - Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks) in Austria:

## Institute of Citizen Science

The Institute of Citizen Science for Satelite & Wireless Communication (ICSSW) cooperates with the Vienna regional association in the ÖVSV in training. Additionally, the Institute of Citizen Science (ISCCS) is a platform dedicated to the promotion and exploration of resilient communication methods through modern amateur radio, with innovative technologies such as LoRa, MeshCom, APRS and HAMNET (IP radio relay) playing a central role.

## BOS-ARSA (Amateur Radio Organization for Security Authorities)

The members of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks (BOS) who have acquired an amateur radio license founded the "Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria (BOS-ARSA)". The goal is to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

The search results show that citizen science, amateur radio training, and emergency preparedness communication networks are all interconnected within Austria's research and emergency response infrastructure.

## Wolfgang Gabrutsch OE8GWQ

Wolfgang Gabrutsch is an amateur radio enthusiast based in Feistritz im Rosental, and is a police officer. 

In 2019, Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Security Responsibilities, known as BOS-ARSA. He reports on the BOS-ARSA project, which is an emergency radio project with connections to the radio services of emergency organizations.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about ADL 820 and BOS-ARSA:

## ADL 820 - BOS-ARSA Overview

ADL 820 is the amateur radio club of members of authorities and organizations with security tasks (BOS) who have acquired amateur radio licenses, officially known as the Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria (BOS-ARSA).

## Purpose and Goals

The association aims at organizing and creating interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks within the scope of crisis and disaster communication.

## Location and Leadership

Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch, BA MBA MBA (OE8GWQ) serves as president and is located at the Landespolizeidirektion Kärnten in Klagenfurt am Wörthersee.

## Activities

Currently, no club meetings are held; the most important activity is the crisis communication exercise every Sunday at 19:00 on the LAWZ 2m repeater at 145.7625 MHz FM with 88.5 Hz subtone.

## Historical Context

Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the BOS-ARSA in 2019, and the association currently has nearly 80 members.

Based on the web search results, I found relevant information about BOS-ARSA related to amateur radio:

## BOS-ARSA Overview

The members of authorities and organizations with safety responsibilities (BOS) who have acquired an amateur radio license founded the "Austrian Amateur Radio Association of Authorities and Organizations with Safety Responsibilities – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria (BOS-ARSA)".

## Purpose and Mission

The goal of the association is the organization and creation of interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV and the emergency dispatch centers of authorities and organizations with safety responsibilities within the framework of crisis and disaster communication.

## Practical Implementation

Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of a blackout or other failure of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA has a fixed place at the emergency services meeting, and the establishment of a radio station in the emergency operations center of the district office is planned.

# BOS-ARSA Information Extract

## Organization Details

**BOS-ARSA** (Österreichischer Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben / Austrian Amateur Radio Society of Authorities and Security Organizations) is a non-profit association focused on amateur radio within Austrian emergency and security services.

## Leadership

- **President:** Gabrutsch Wolfgang, BA MBA MBA DBA
- **Secretary General:** Londer Erich, BA
- **Treasurer:** Ing. René Camaur
- **Additional officers:** Joham Thomas, Kugi Jürgen, Weger Erwin

## Stated Goals

The organization aims to "preserve, promote and disseminate amateur radio activities within the scope of authorities and organizations with security tasks."

## Contact & Legal Information

- **Email:** office@bos-arsa.at
- **Location:** Klagenfurt am Wörthersee, Austria
- **Regulatory Authority:** Landespolizeidirektion Kärnten
- **ZVR Number:** 1783847541

## Search Results

**No references found** to:
- QSP magazine
- Publications or press mentions
- Specific callsigns (OE8OPT, OE8GWQ, OE8AWZ)
- Timeline of events or articles

The webpage functions primarily as an organizational homepage with membership recruitment focus.

# Amateur Radio Training Article Analysis

## Title
"Amateur Radio Training 'The World Without Borders'"

## Date
December 8, 2022

## Article Summary

This article announces an **online amateur radio training course** for winter 2023 conducted by the Institute of Citizen Science for Satellite & Wireless Communication (ICSSW) in cooperation with Vienna's ÖVSV regional association.

### Key Content:

**Training Overview:**
The course prepares students for official telecommunications exams in three classes: VHF radio, VHF/KW radio, and VHF/KW with homebrew capabilities. The article emphasizes that "the fun of experimenting and the common radio experience should always be in the foreground."

**Course Structure:**
- Kick-off meeting: January 27, 2023
- Classes: February/March 2023
- Time commitment: 27-42 hours depending on exam class
- Includes review sessions and mock exam

**Contact:**
Ing. Kurt Baumann (OE1KBC), Course Instructor
Email: oe1kbc@oevsv.at

## Findings Regarding Your Specific Query

**BOS-ARSA, Gabrutsch, and Emergency Communications:**
The article contains **no mentions** of BOS-ARSA, Gabrutsch, or emergency communications training. The focus is exclusively on recreational amateur radio training and hobby preparation for telecommunications authority examinations.

content.content:
# Article Analysis

## Title
"Resilient communication in a crisis... through modern amateur radio and citizen science"

## Date
The article does not display a specific publication date in the provided content.

## Main Content
This article is an introductory page for the Institute of Citizen Science (ICSSW), promoting resilient communication methods. The piece explains that the organization focuses on "the promotion and exploration of resilient communication methods through modern amateur radio."

The article highlights four primary technologies:
- **LoRa**: Long-range, low-power communication
- **MeshCom**: Self-organizing, self-healing networks
- **APRS**: Real-time location and telemetry systems
- **HAMNET**: High-speed multimedia networks for amateur radio

The content emphasizes community engagement, knowledge-sharing, and building "robust connections" for reliable communication in emergency situations and remote areas.

## Specific Mentions
The document contains **no mentions** of BOS-ARSA, Gabrutsch, OE8GWQ, or detailed emergency communications protocols. The only personal attribution is "(mike zwingl oe3mzc)" at the conclusion.

## Summary

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about your query:

A technical discussion on emergency communications and BOS-ARSA-ADL820 took place at Pressegger See on July 10, 2024. OE3KYS, OE8IMK, OE8SCQ, OE8OWK, OE8FCK, OE8GWQ and PE1AVP exchanged their experiences and developed ideas for the future.

OE8SCQ presented the infrastructure for QSOs via QO100. The event was significant for establishing ongoing collaboration: Due to the need for alternative communication options in case of blackouts or other failures of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA received a permanent place at the Blaulicht-Stammtisch (emergency services regulars table).

Additionally, the establishment of a club radio station in the command center of the Völkermarkt district authority is planned, which will be staffed by BOS amateur radio operators in crisis and disaster cases and operated in the area of the message collection point, ensuring communication to emergency radio operators in light islands of municipalities for emergency support in case of failure of conventional communication means.

Based on the search results, I found information about Wolfgang Gabrutsch and his work related to amateur radio (Amateurfunk) and law enforcement in Carinthia (Kärnten), Austria:

## Key Findings:

Wolfgang Gabrutsch is a colonel (Oberst) police officer based in Feistritz im Rosental who is involved in amateur radio, having come to the hobby relatively recently and not from a technical background.

Before becoming involved in amateur radio, Gabrutsch served for 24 years as a fire department commander and was previously a radio officer. In 2019, he completed his amateur radio training and examination, obtaining his radio license, which qualifies him to work with 100-watt devices and build them himself.

In 2019, Wolfgang Gabrutsch founded the Austrian Amateur Radio Association for Authorities and Organizations with Security Tasks (BOS-ARSA), an organization where radio operators from blue-light organizations with amateur radio licenses can participate.

In 2019, a training course and amateur radio examination were held at the State Police Directorate in Klagenfurt as part of Carinthia's crisis management framework, with Gabrutsch providing significant support with motivation and effort.

Dr. Wolfgang Gabrutsch, with the radio call sign OE8GWQ, serves as president of BOS-ARSA and is based at the Carinthian State Police Directorate in Klagenfurt.

I found search results related to your query about BOS-ARSA and crisis communication exercises. Here's what the search revealed:

BOS-ARSA (Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria) is an organization founded by members of authorities and organizations with security tasks who have obtained amateur radio licenses. The organization's goal is to create interfaces between the existing emergency radio system of the ÖVSV (Austrian Amateur Radio Association) and the control centers of authorities and organizations with security tasks in the context of crisis and disaster communication.

Regarding the specific exercise you mentioned ("Übung Krisenkommunikation Sonntag 2m Relais LAWZ" - Sunday crisis communication exercise 2m relay), the search results provide context on relevant terms:

- LAWZ refers to Alarm- und Warnzentralen (Alarm and Warning Centers)
- 2-m refers to a waveband (2-meter band) used in analog BOS radio, with field radio operations primarily taking place in the 2-meter waveband.

However, the search results do not contain specific details about the particular Sunday exercise you're inquiring about. For more information about this specific exercise, you may want to contact BOS-ARSA directly at www.bos-arsa.at or office@bos-arsa.at.

# Article Analysis: Amateur Radio Operators and Emergency Communications

## Article Details

**Title:** Funkamateure schließen Kommunikationslücke im Notfall (Amateur Radio Operators Close Communication Gap in Emergency)

**Date:** September 19, 2024

**Author:** Deutscher Amateur-Radio-Club e.V. (German Amateur Radio Club)

**Geographic Focus:** Germany (Baunatal mentioned as club headquarters)

## Key Points About Amateur Radio's Emergency Role

The article explains that radio amateurs can rapidly establish independent digital networks when infrastructure fails. Their capabilities include:

- **Emergency telephone connections** for hospitals and rescue services when regular communication systems collapse
- **Data transmission** between emergency responders (rescue services, fire departments, police)
- **Public information dissemination** when conventional channels like mobile networks fail

The article notes: "Mit ihrem mobilen Equipment sind Funkamateure in der Lage, binnen kürzester Zeit eigenständige, digitale Netzwerke aufzubauen" (Mobile equipment enables amateurs to establish independent digital networks within minimal timeframe).

## Notable Context

The article references enhanced capabilities developed following the Ahrtal catastrophe, indicating evolution of crisis communication techniques.

## No Mentions Found

The article contains **no references to BOS-ARSA, Gabrutsch, OE8GWQ, Kärnten, or Austria**.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about BOS-ARSA in Carinthia (Kärnten):

BOS-ARSA is the "Österreichischen Amateurfunkverein der Behörden und Organisationen mit Sicherheitsaufgaben – BOS-Amateur-Radio-Society-Austria," an organization founded by members of authorities and organizations with security responsibilities who have acquired amateur radio licenses.

The search results show that BOS-ARSA held a welcoming event for participants of a DX-Camp in Döbriach am Millstätter See in July, which included an afternoon with amateur radio enthusiasts from across Austria.

Additionally, the president of BOS-ARSA presented the organization's goals at a "Blaulicht-Stammtisch" (blue light regular table) in Völkermarkt, and due to the need for alternative communication options in case of blackouts or failure of critical infrastructure, BOS-ARSA received a permanent place at this regular meeting.

The website kaernten-funkt.at itself did not appear directly in the search results, but the search did return information about BOS-ARSA activities in Carinthia.
